head.title: Unveiling Electrode–Electrolyte Design-Based NO Reduction for NH3 Synthesis | ACS Energy Letters

meta.content: Unveiling Electrode–Electrolyte Design-Based NO Reduction for NH3 Synthesis

The electrochemical N2 reduction reaction has attracted interest as a potential alternative to the Haber–Bosch process, but a significantly low conversion efficiency and a significantly low ammonia production rate stimulate the need for alternatives. Here, we represent the electrochemical reduction of nitric oxide (NO) on a nanostructured Ag electrode in combination with a rationally designed electrolyte containing the EDTA–Fe2+ metal complex (EFeMC), which results in an ∼100% efficiency for NH3 with a current density of 50 mA/cm2 at −0.165 VRHE, without any degradation in catalytic activity or product selectivity up to 120 h. Economic analysis using itemized cost estimation predicted that the synthesis of ammonia from NO reduction in an EFeMC-designed electrolyte can be market competitive at an electricity price of $0.03 kWh–1 with a current density of >125 mA/cm2. Therefore, this approach opens an entirely new avenue of renewable electricity-driven ammonia synthesis.

div.span: Supporting Info (1)
SUBJECTS:

div.p:
The electrochemical N
2
reduction reaction has attracted interest as a potential alternative to the Haber–Bosch process, but a significantly low conversion efficiency and a significantly low ammonia production rate stimulate the need for alternatives. Here, we represent the electrochemical reduction of nitric oxide (NO) on a nanostructured Ag electrode in combination with a rationally designed electrolyte containing the EDTA–Fe
2+
metal complex (EFeMC), which results in an ∼100% efficiency for NH
3
with a current density of 50 mA/cm
2
at −0.165 V
RHE
, without any degradation in catalytic activity or product selectivity up to 120 h. Economic analysis using itemized cost estimation predicted that the synthesis of ammonia from NO reduction in an EFeMC-designed electrolyte can be market competitive at an electricity price of $0.03 kWh
–1
with a current density of >125 mA/cm
2
. Therefore, this approach opens an entirely new avenue of renewable electricity-driven ammonia synthesis.

Ammonia (NH
3
) is the mainstay for both human life and the earth’s ecology as it is used for a wide range of applications such as fertilizer, pharmaceuticals, textiles, and plastic fields. Moreover, recently reported applications of NH
3
as a promising carbon-free hydrogen energy carrier and as a promising CO
2
emission-free transportation fuel have significantly enhanced the demand and stature of NH
3
.
(1−5)
To date, industrial-scale NH
3
production mainly relies on the Haber–Bosch process, which is energy- and capital-intensive and raises serious environmental concerns due to high CO
2
emission as a byproduct.
(1,2,4,6−9)
To resolve these issues, there is an urgent need to look for energy-efficient and environmentally friendly ways to synthesize ammonia. The electrochemical nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) and the electro-thermochemical looping approach (looping-NH
3
) have attracted a great deal of attention with substantial progress in recent years as a clean and energy-saving approach for NH
3
synthesis.
(7,9−16)
Nevertheless, a large activation barrier (941 kJ/mol) for N
2
dissociation, low solubility and sluggish transport of N
2
, and competitive hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) are significant challenges that still ought to be addressed to scale up NRR to the industrial level.
(6)
To date, tremendous research effort, including integrated efforts with catalysts, an electrolyte, and a system, has been spent for the improvement of NRR, but NRR is still in its infancy with weak selectivity, limited yields, and low faradic efficiencies (FEs).
(6)
Very recently, Long et al. reported an alternative route for the synthesis of NH
3
from nitric oxide (NO) using Cu foam as an electrocatalyst and obtained a high FE (93.5%) as well as a high production rate (517.1 μmol cm
–2
h
–1
).
(17)
Although the concept is highly inspiring and presents a new scenario for reusing the exhaust NO gas, the direct use of a high concentration of NO gas in the report may be a main limitation for its commercial application because an extra facility is required to concentrate NO gas from the exhaust gas.

Herein, we represent electrode–electrolyte design-based NO reduction as an alternative approach for electrochemical NH
3
synthesis by using a controlled amount of NO instead of N
2
. The use of a precise amount of NO provides new insights for resolving the limitations of NRR as well as safety limitations of using highly concentrated NO gas. In addition, a relatively high standard reduction potential of NO (0.77 V
RHE
) can minimize the competition with HER (0 V
RHE
) in the electrochemical NO reduction reaction (NORR). In addition, NO is well-known as a heavy pollutant that causes severe environmental issues, including acid rain, ozone depletion, smog, etc.
(18,19)
Clearly, the synthesis of NH
3
from controlled NORR may be a beneficial alternative in both aspects, commercial and environmental. At a low concentration, the low solubility of NO in water (∼1.94 mM at 25 °C) is expected to affect the rate of production of ammonia from direct NORR in aqueous electrolytes.
(20)
Therefore, to stimulate the high but controlled solubility of NO (≤200 mM) in an electrolyte, we used the EDTA–Fe
2+
metal complex (EFeMC) for electrolyte design, which is known for its rapid NO capture ability.
(21,22)
The ligand among EFeMC not only prevents the precipitation of iron where NO adsorption occurs but also stabilizes NO to form NO adsorbed on a metal complex (
[email protected]
).
(23)
The proof of concept for electrochemical ammonia synthesis and its utilization are shown in
Scheme S1
. Although EFeMC has been reported previously as a NO-capturing agent,
(21)
the specified role and/or contribution of EFeMC as an executor of NORR toward selective and efficient ammonia synthesis still needs to be unraveled.

Therefore, we take advantage of an EFeMC-designed electrolyte to investigate the electrochemical reduction of NO for ammonia synthesis. Gaseous NO was captured by an EFeMC-designed electrolyte, consisting of 50 mM metal complex in a neutral-pH phosphate buffer solution (PBS), and filled in a cathode chamber of an H-type electrolysis cell that is equipped with working, counter (Pt foil), and reference (Ag/AgCl) electrodes (
Figure
1
a and
Figure S1
). Further details regarding the electrochemical cell configuration are given in the
experimental procedures in the Supporting Information
. Silver (Ag) was chosen as a preferable cathode material because of its ability to sufficiently suppress the HER,
(24,25)
while Pt foil and glassy carbon (GC) were also used as cathode materials for control experiments.

Figure 1. Electrochemical NORR in PBS-MC
50
-NO
s
and PBS-MC
50
-Ar electrolytes on different cathode materials: platinum (Pt), glassy carbon (GC), and silver (Ag). (a) Schematic diagram showing NO capture by EFeMC present in the electrolyte and its electrochemical reduction to ammonia. (b) Linear sweep voltammograms (LSVs) for Pt, GC, and Ag electrodes for the electrochemical NORR in PBS-MC
50
-NO
s
and PBS-MC
50
-Ar electrolytes. (c) Faradic efficiencies and current densities for the formation of NH
4
+
in the potential range of −0.55 to 0 V. Values were averaged, and error bars indicate the standard deviation (
n
= 3 replicates).

Before NORR was measured, the differences in electrochemical behavior of three working electrodes were determined by measuring their linear sweep voltammograms (LSVs) in an Ar gas-purged EFeMC electrolyte (PBS-MC
50
-Ar) and NO gas saturated EFeMC electrolyte (PBS-MC
50
-NO
s
) (
Figure
1
b). It is clear from
Figure
1
b that the Ag electrode showed a distinct reduction wave at −0.3 V
RHE
in a PBS-MC
50
-NO
s
electrolyte when NO adsorbed on metal complex (
[email protected]
) species was present in the catholyte; however, no such reduction wave was observed for PBS-MC
50
-Ar that did not contain adsorbed NO. GC also exhibited a reduction wave starting at approximately −0.4 V
RHE
in the PBS-MC
50
-NO
s
electrolyte, while contrary to Ag and GC, the Pt foil electrode exhibited the same onset potential (−0.05 V
RHE
) in PBS-MC
50
-NO
s
and PBS-MC
50
-Ar electrolytes without any appearance of a reduction wave. These quite distinguished features of Pt compared to Ag and GC suggest that HER was spontaneous and dominant reaction on Pt, while on Ag and GC, the
[email protected]
species was involved in the electrochemical reaction.

To understand better the influence of EFeMC in a NO-saturated electrolyte, it is important to study interactions between
[email protected]
species and cathode surfaces by electrochemically monitoring their adsorption–desorption characteristics under applied potentials. For this, each working electrode was immersed in a PBS-MC
50
-NO
s
electrolyte and constant potentials (0.1 and −0.3 V
RHE
) were applied for 1 min in a three-electrode cell configuration (without an ion exchange membrane) for the adsorption of
[email protected]
species. Each soaked electrode was then transferred to PBS without an EFeMC additive for electrochemical stripping tests.
(26)
The observed results (
Figure S2
) revealed that no adlayer peak current corresponding to
[email protected]
adsorbates was observed for any working electrode, which suggests that
[email protected]
species or a reaction intermediate was not bound to the electrode surfaces strongly in a PBS-MC
50
-NO
s
electrolyte. This led us to suggest that the
[email protected]
species are most likely to be located in the outer sphere of the Helmholtz plane, thereby taking up charges from the electrode via an outer-sphere electron transfer. In addition, the electrochemical behavior of
[email protected]
species at different scan rates was measured for the Ag electrode (
Figure S3
) exhibiting a linear dependence of the peak current with the square root of the scan rates, which indicates that the electrochemical reduction of
[email protected]
species present in the PBS-MC
50
-NO
s
electrolyte is diffusion-controlled in the determined potential window.

The NORR in the PBS-MC
50
-NO
s
electrolyte was measured on a Pt electrode (
Figure S4
), a GC electrode (
Figure S5
), and a Ag electrode (
Figure S6
) through chronoamperometry (CA) measurement at various constant applied potentials for 1 h. To identify and quantify possible reaction products during the potential cycling, online gas and ex situ ion chromatography techniques (
Figures S7–S9
) were employed for the analyses of gaseous (H
2
and N
2
O) and liquid products (NH
4
+
and NH
3
OH
+
), respectively. Details for NORR product analysis and corresponding calculations for faradic efficiencies of products can be found in the
Supporting Information
. Calculated results of FE of products for NORR in the PBS-MC
50
-NO
s
electrolyte on Pt (
Figure S4e
), GC (
Figure S5e
), and Ag (
Figure S6e
) demonstrated that only the Ag and GC electrode exhibit nearly 100% FE for ammonia (as ammonium, NH
4
+
) production in potential ranges of −0.15 to −0.29 V
RHE
and −0.29 to −0.34 V
RHE
, respectively, while Pt exhibited only ∼30% FE and 1.99 mA/cm
2
partial current density for NH
4
+
as shown in
Figure
1
c. It is clear from
Figure
1
c that as compared to the GC electrode, the Ag electrode displayed a lower overpotential and a wider potential range for selective NH
4
+
production (
Figures S4c–S6c
). Moreover, the Ag electrode shows the highest partial current density for NH
4
+
(3.81 mA/cm
2
) with the corresponding NH
4
+
production rate of 0.28 mol m
–2
h
–1
(
Figure
1
c). Tafel analysis of Pt, GC, and Ag electrodes for NORR in a PBS-MC
50
-NO
s
electrolyte with partial NH
4
+
current densities showed that the Tafel slope for Pt (66 mV/decade) is much lower than those of Ag (201 mV/decade) and GC (235 mV/decade) electrodes as represented in
Figure S10
, implying the presence of the NORR pathway with faster electron transfer (ET) kinetics on Pt than on Ag or GC. We conceive that the NORR on the metal surface via the inner-sphere ET could provide a faster ET kinetics than the NORR at the EFeMC via the outer-sphere ET, and thus, the former pathway would prevail on Pt. However, the Pt surface is more active for HER despite its fast electron transfer kinetics for the NORR. We further performed electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (ESI) to measure the charge transfer resistance (
R
ct
) of Ag, Pt, and GC electrodes. Our experimental results indicate that the
R
ct
of Ag is ∼162 Ω versus ∼15 Ω for Pt and ∼346 Ω for GC, consistent with the trend of Tafel slopes (
Figure S11
). Additionally, trace amounts of nitrous oxide (N
2
O) were detected from the reduction (
Figures S4e–S6e
), but no other nitrogen-containing species such as nitrogen gas (N
2
) or hydroxylamine (hydroxylammonium, NH
3
OH
+
) was detected. Meanwhile, the concentration of fully converted NH
4
+
was approximately equal to that of EFeMC, indicating a 1:1 stoichiometric correlation consistent with the literature
(27)
(
Figure S12
).

Although initially we used EFeMC in our electrolyte as the NO capturing agent, another main aspect of interest in this work was to elaborate the important role of EFeMC as an executor toward highly selective NORR to NH
4
+
. First, to clarify the effect of EFeMC toward NH
4
+
selectivity, we investigated the electrochemical NORR on each electrode without EFeMC additives in PBS (termed a blank electrolyte) as shown in
Figures S4–S6
. In other words, pure NO gas was directly introduced into the PBS (PBS-NO)-filled cathodic compartment of the electrolytic cell at a constant flow rate (5 sccm). Note that N
2
O, which was present in only trace amounts across all of the potentials in the PBS-MC
50
-NO
s
electrolyte, was the dominant product in the PBS-NO at low overpotentials (
Figures S4f–S6f
). This indicates that the accessibility of free NO molecules is inherently required in the electrolyte for N–N dimerization (N
2
O formation), which is consistent with the previously reported N–N coupling mechanism of Koper and co-workers.
(26,28,29)
Given the assertion of this fact, we expected that such dimerization is not easily possible in the PBS-MC
50
-NO
s
electrolyte due to the unavailability of the free NO molecule because of the presence of EFeMC in electrolytes so that the available NO exists only in the bounded state, i.e.,
[email protected]
species. The FE for N
2
O formation during NORR in PBS-NO decreased with an increase in overpotential, and NH
3
OH
+
and NH
4
+
started to form at the expense of N
2
O formation. Such a switching behavior of the dominant product from N
2
O at low overpotentials to ammonia at high overpotentials is explained well using the DFT-calculated reaction free energetics shown in
Figure S13
. In high overpotential regions (less than −0.32 V
RHE
, less than −0.35 V
RHE
, and less than −0.45 V
RHE
for Pt, Ag, and GC, respectively), NH
3
OH
+
was no longer detected but NH
4
+
was the sole N-containing product, while HER also occurred at those potential regions resulting in the loss of faradic efficiency (
Figures S4f–S6f
). In short, from these control experiments, we speculate that the presence of EFeMC in electrolytes is the factor responsible for the superior selectivity of NORR into NH
4
+
.

Because the Ag electrode showed an NH
4
+
production rate (0.28 mol m
–2
h
–1
) that was higher than those of GC and Pt electrodes, the electrochemical study of potential intermediates, i.e., NH
3
OH
+
and N
2
O, will be focused only on the Ag electrode for mechanistic understanding of the essential role of EFeMC. The electrochemical reduction of NH
3
OH
+
on Ag in a blank electrolyte, i.e., PBS, led to the immediate formation of NH
4
+
at an onset potential of approximately −0.26 V (
Figure
2
a). We noted that the direct reduction of NH
3
OH
+
to NH
4
+
required an overpotential of approximately 0.1 V more than that required for NH
4
+
formation in the PBS-MC
50
-NO
s
electrolyte, which indicates that the NH
3
OH
+
intermediate formed during NORR might have been electronically influenced by the presence of EFeMC. In contrast to NH
3
OH
+
, N
2
O, which is a representative N–N dimerization species, showed almost no electrochemical activity upon application of cathodic potentials, confirming that N
2
O was not an intermediate of NH
4
+
formation.

Figure 2. Mechanistic insights into the electrochemical NORR in an EFeMC-designed electrolyte. (a) Linear sweep voltammograms for the Ag electrode in a phosphate-buffered electrolyte (PBS) containing 50 mM NH
2
OH (PBS-NH
2
OH), in PBS containing NO-adsorbed 50 mM EFeMC (PBS-MC
50
-NO
s
), and in PBS saturated with Ar (PBS-Ar) and N
2
O (PBS-N
2
O). (b) Chemical interaction between NH
3
OH
+
and EFeMC. Effect of NH
3
OH
+
concentration and applied potentials. (c) Structures and reaction free energy diagram obtained from density functional theory (DFT) calculations [where *(II) ≡ EFeMC].

To further determine the interactions of NH
3
OH
+
species with EFeMC and subsequent pH-dependent possible conversion pathways of NH
3
OH
+
into N
2
O or NH
4
+
,
(30−32)
we performed chemical and electrochemical studies of EFeMC with various concentrations of NH
3
OH
+
(2, 5, 10, and 20 mM). First, for the chemical interactions, PBS-MC
50
-Ar and PBS-MC
50
-NO
s
were mixed separately with equal amounts of hydroxylamine sulfate [(NH
2
OH)
2
·H
2
SO
4
] solutions and the reactions were analyzed every 15 min for 1 h (
Figure S14
). We found that NH
3
OH
+
reacted at the open-circuit potential (OCP, in the range between −0.2 and −0.1 V) and the chemical conversion of NH
3
OH
+
to NH
4
+
proceeded spontaneously in PBS-MC
50
-Ar. An approximately 81% conversion efficiency was achieved in the presence of 2 mM NH
3
OH
+
in PBS-MC
50
-Ar, but with an increase in NH
3
OH
+
concentration, a decrease was observed in conversion efficiency (
Figure
2
b and
Figure S14a
). The time-based analysis of the mixed solution also revealed that most of the conversion occurred during the first 15 min and then plateaued (
Figure S14b
). On the contrary, we found that approximately 35% of NH
3
OH
+
was converted into N
2
O at OCP when hydroxylamine sulfate was mixed with PBS-MC
50
-NO
s
(
Figure S15d
), indicating some interaction between NH
3
OH
+
and
[email protected]
species. It is possible that in this case Fe
2+
in EFeMC may be oxidized into Fe
3+
, resulting in a weakened NO binding ability. Thus, free NO molecules desorbed from the metal complexes may react with NH
3
OH
+
either chemically or electrochemically, leading to the formation of N
2
O (
Table S1
).
(27,33)
Furthermore, the electrochemical reduction of Fe
3+
to Fe
2+
in the complex would take place in the operation potential range, indicating EFeMC, as an electron mediator, can be involved in the electron transfer.

Now to examine the electrochemical interactions of NH
3
OH
+
species with EFeMC, we performed CA experiments for 1 h at 0.26, −0.24, and −0.43 V
RHE
in a mixture of 20 mM (NH
2
OH)
2
·H
2
SO
4
in PBS-MC
50
-Ar and PBS-MC
50
-NO
s
. At 0.26 and −0.24 V
RHE
(
Figure S15
), at which NH
3
OH
+
cannot be reduced electrochemically (
Figure
2
a), NH
3
OH
+
was completely converted to NH
4
+
in PBS-MC
50
-Ar (
Figure S15b
) while a trace amount of N
2
O was also produced along with NH
4
+
in the case of PBS-MC
50
-NO
s
(
Figure S15d
). Moreover, at a potential of 0.26 V
RHE
where neither NH
3
OH
+
nor the ferrous complex shows any electrochemical activity, the complete conversion was noted.

As the investigation of the electroreduction pathway of NO bound to EFeMC is crucial for studying the reaction mechanism, DFT calculations and the computational hydrogen electrode (CHE) method
(34)
were used for considering an outer-sphere mechanism. The details of computational calculations are provided in the
Supporting Information
. The DFT energetics of the possible intermediate species (
Figure S16
) indicated that the sequential hydrogenation of NO through proton-coupled electron transfer favors the HNO pathway over the NOH pathway (
Figure S17
), i.e., via *(II)–NO → *(II)–HNO → *(II)–NHOH → *(II)–NH
2
OH → *(II)–NH
2
+ H
2
O → *(II)–NH
3
+ H
2
O [where *(II) = EFeMC]. The possible intermediate structures based on DFT with corresponding reaction free energy values are shown in
Figure
2
c. Notably, the *HNO intermediate was determined to be the rate-limiting species, which is also consistent with the previously reported DFT results on a similar system.
(35)
However, it is specifically stabilized through H-bond formation with the ligand present in a metal complex, as shown in the DFT-optimized structures (upper insets of
Figure
2
c), demonstrating the EDTA provides a favorable reaction free energetics and is involved in the electron transfer process. The onset potential of NORR is calculated to be −0.34 V
RHE
, comparable with the experimental onset potential (−0.3 V
RHE
) on the GC electrode where the dominance of the outer-sphere mechanism is expected. Furthermore, an anodic shift of ∼0.1 V in the onset potential for NORR on the Ag electrode implies a certain catalytic role of Ag toward NORR, which will be investigated and discussed later in the text. In addition, we note that the possibility of chemical conversion of NH
3
OH
+
to NH
4
+
was supported by the DFT energetics (
Figure S17
).

For the purpose of enhancing catalytic performance, we fabricated a nanostructured silver (Agn) electrode by a chlorination/dechlorination method (
Figure
3
a) and then its structural effect was investigated for NH
3
production. The details are provided in the experimental procedure in the
Supporting Information
. The scanning electron microscopy (SEM) analysis of the fabricated Agn electrode revealed the formation of a nanocoral structure on the surface of Ag foil (
Figure
3
b). However, the crystallinity and electronic structure of the Agn electrode remain unaltered as confirmed by their X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns (
Figure
3
c) and ex situ X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) (
Figure
3
d and
Figure S18
). Except for the presence of some intercalated chloride ions (Cl
–
) (
Figure S18c
), the Agn electrode exactly matches with the (111), (200), (220), and (311) planes of Ag (JCPDS File 04-0783) and both have similar Ag 3d and Ag MVV structures. Surface roughening of Ag resulted in an increased double-layer capacitance (43.4 mF/cm
2
) that is approximately 400 times higher than that of the Ag foil electrode (
Figure S19
), although the turnover frequency (TOF) was decreased. When comparing the NORR in the PBS-MC
50
-NO
s
electrolyte on Ag foil and Agn electrodes, we observed that the Agn electrode exhibited a more positively shifted onset potential (+0.04 V
RHE
) with an approximately 3-fold increase in peak current density (
Figure
4
a), which can be attributed to the reduced charge transfer resistance via the surface roughening process of Ag (i.e.,
R
ct
of Agn of ∼18 Ω vs 162 Ω for Ag foil) (
Figures S11 and S20
). Like on the Ag foil electrode (
Figure S2
), the interaction between the
[email protected]
species and Agn electrode surface has also been analyzed by monitoring adsorption–desorption characteristics electrochemically under applied potentials of −0.1 and 0.3 V
RHE
for 1 min and their electrochemical stripping activities have been recorded. The lack of the appearance of any adlayer peak current suggests that the
[email protected]
species was not bound strongly to Agn electrode surfaces (
Figure S21
).

Figure 4. Performance of Agn for the electrochemical NORR in PBS-MC
x
-NO
s
electrolytes to NH
4
+
. (a) Linear sweep voltammograms in the potential range of 0.2 to −0.4 V

for Ag and Agn electrodes in PBS-MC

electrolytes, where

(50, 100, and 200 mM) is the concentration of EFeMC in PBS. (b) Effect of applied potentials on NH
4
+
faradic efficiencies and NH

+
partial current density for the Agn electrode in PBS-MC
200
-NO
s
electrolytes. (c) Repetitive chronoamperometric scans and NH
4
+
faradic efficiencies (top) for the Agn electrode in PBS-MC

s
at −0.165 V
RHE
. Amount of NH
4
+
produced and accumulated in repetitive batch tests (bottom) for the Agn electrode in PBS-MC

at −0.165 V

. (d) Long-term stability of the Agn electrode at −0.165 V

in a flow cell system with the PBS-MC
200

electrolyte.

To understand the catalytic role of Ag during NORR in the PBS-MC
50
-NO
s
electrolyte, DFT calculations were used to investigate the interaction between the silver nanoparticle (Ag NP) and the possible intermediate structures. Interestingly, even the small 13-atom Ag NP (chosen due to the limited computational cost) demonstrated unfavorable binding energetics with
[email protected]
species despite the presence of many exposed undercoordinated Ag atoms at the surface. These computational results support the experimental observation of the absence of adlayer peak current (
Figure S21
). However, the Ag NP developed a donor–acceptor interaction with the oxygen atoms of other intermediate–EFeMC structures [*(II)–HNO, *(II)–NHOH, and *(II)–NH
2
OH, where *(II) = EFeMC] as shown in
Figure S22b–e
, which substantially stabilized these intermediates (
Figure S23
). Thus, on the basis of computational results, we conclude that the undercoordinated sites on the Ag surface participate in the catalytic mechanism by stabilizing the key reaction intermediates (except NO) via a donor–acceptor interaction, which explains the anodic shift in the onset potential of nanostructured Agn without the specific adsorption of the
[email protected]

The CA experiments for 1 h at different potentials on a nanostructured Agn electrode in the PBS-MC
50
-NO
s
electrolyte have been measured, and the analysis of product distribution shown in
Figure S24
reveals that NH
4
+
was selectively produced over a wide potential range (0.04 to −0.34 V
RHE
) on the Agn electrodes. Moreover, an increase in EFeMC concentration in the electrolyte (from 50 to 200 mM) to reduce diffusion limitation results in a further enhanced current density (∼34 mA/cm
2
) (
Figure
4
a), which corresponds to the maximum NH
4
+
production rate of 2.29 mol m
–2
h
–1
(
Figure
4
b). To verify which factor, either nanostructured cathode or increased EFeMC concentration, has altered the reaction kinetics, we performed Tafel analyses (
Figure S25
). Both the nanostructured Agn and foil Ag electrodes exhibited similar Tafel slopes (201 mV/decade) in the same electrolyte, which suggests that the Agn electrode does not enhance the reaction kinetics for the reduction of NO bound to EFeMC. However, with an increased concentration of
[email protected]
, the Agn electrode showed an improved electron transfer kinetics (168 mV/decade) despite the transport limitations.

Moreover, it is also reasonable to suspect that in the case of the nanostructured Agn electrode, the intercalated Cl
–
(
Figure S18c
) may also affect the enhanced NORR in the PBS-MC
50
-NO
s
electrolyte. To examine the effect of Cl
–
ions, we measured the NORR in the PBS-MC
50
-NO
s
electrolyte in the presence of different concentrations of KCl (10, 25, 50, and 100 mM) in the electrolyte (
Figure S26
). The observed LSV curves and product distributions of the electrolyte containing additional Cl
–
ions showed almost identical performance in terms of current densities and faradic efficiencies (
Figure S26b
). This confirms that the Cl
–
ions have a minimal effect on the electrochemical reduction activity of
[email protected]
and, further, supports the importance of nanostructured Agn toward performance enhancement. In addition to this, further isotope labeling experiments was carried out to exclude contamination issues caused by nitrogen sources.
15
[email protected]
was prepared by saturating
15
NO gas in an EFeMC-designed electrolyte, and then we performed a CA experiment on Agn at −0.34 V
RHE
. The NMR spectra of the electrolyte after reaction exhibited double peaks (δ = 6.88 and 6.99 ppm) that exactly matched with the typical peaks on
15
NH
4
+
, demonstrating NH
4
+
detected in our experiment originated from the reduction of NO (
Figure S27a
). The quantification of generated
15
NH
4
+
after electrolysis was carried out by NMR, and the calculated
15
NH
4
+
FE was 98.7% (
Figure S27b
), which is very consistent with IC results.

The stability of the EFeMC as a NO carrier was tested by recycling the PBS-MC
200
-NO
s
electrolyte (200 mM EFeMC dissolved in PBS) in a batch-type cell (
Figure
4
c). After each CA cycle at −0.165 V
RHE
, the electrolyte in the cathodic chamber was sparged with fresh NO gas for 15 min to adsorb NO back to EFeMC species in the electrolyte. Before additional CA cycles were started, the electrolyte was purged with Ar gas to remove any residual free NO. We confirmed that neither the EFeMC nor the Agn electrode degraded after repeated electrochemical tests at −0.165 V
RHE
and could accumulate up to 0.76 M NH
4
+
after five cycles. Compared with the theoretical yield, approximately 76% of NO in the EFeMC was converted to NH
4
+
. The rapid decrease in current density during each cycle of the electrochemical tests was attributed to the consumption of NO adsorbed on EFeMC in the electrolyte. In addition, the activity and stability of the EFeMC were also tested in a flow cell in which a large volume of the PBS-MC
200
-NO
s
electrolyte was circulated at a flow rate of 20 mL min
–1
from an outside reservoir, and the maximum NH
4
+
current density of 48 mA/cm
2
, which is equivalent to an NH
4
+
production rate of 3.6 mol m
–2
h
–1
, was maintained for 120 h with a faradic efficiency of practically 100% at −0.165 V
RHE
(
Figure
4
d) without any observable degradation on nanostructured Agn (
Figures S28 and S29
).

Furthermore, the preliminary economic analysis of the electrochemical production of ammonia from an EFeMC-designed electrolyte using itemized cost estimation (
Tables S2 and S3
) was performed to estimate the approximate cost of this system, which is anticipated at initial stages, and then to confirm whether this technology is economically feasible by comparing it to conventional ammonia production (Haber–Bosch process). In this work, an annual ammonia production rate of 150 million tons year
–1
, which corresponds to global NH
3
production, was considered because it is assumed that the proposed system is used as an alternative to the conventional Haber–Bosch NH
3
production process. From the given conditions such as an NH
4
+
faradic efficiency of 99%, a current density of 48 mA/cm
2
, a cell voltage of 1.65 V
RHE
, and a renewable energy-based electricity price of $0.07 kWh
–1
based on the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) benchmark price estimated from photovoltaic electricity generation in 2016,
(36)
the unit ammonia production cost was estimated as $1.35 (kg of NH
3
)
−1
, which is nearly 2.5 times higher than the commercial price of ammonia [$0.56 (kg of NH
3
)
−1
]. When combined with renewable energies, the cost of producing ammonia electrochemically from NO will be even lower, and the electrochemical reduction of NO in a designed electrolyte may be able to compete with the Haber–Bosch process. The DOE has specifically set the following targets for the electrochemical production of ammonia from N
2
and H
2
O in their REFUEL program: current density of >300 mA/cm
2
, coulombic efficiency of >90%, energy efficiency of >60%, and degradation rate of 0.3%/1000 h. Although the number of electrons required for the reduction of NO is 5/3 times greater and the reactant is different from that of N
2
reduction, in our proposed method, mainly the current density needs to be improved for electrochemical ammonia production, whereas the electrochemical N
2
reduction requires improvements in all of the set target values (
Figure S30
). Therefore, to determine the competitiveness of electrochemical ammonia production using an EFeMC-designed electrolyte, we compared the effect of current density (48–300 mA/cm
2
) and electricity price ($0.00–0.07 kWh
–1
) on the unit ammonia production cost with global renewable electricity prices (weighted average) such as in Chile, the United States, Brazil, India, and the United Kingdom
(37)
(
Figure
5
). We found that the unit ammonia production cost is favorable with a higher current density and a lower electricity price. This implies that the unit ammonia production cost can reach the market price of ammonia if the current density is improved through technological development and the electricity price is decreased by replacement with renewable electricity. With the present renewable energy price of $0.03 kWh
–1
in Chile, our system can reach the market price of ammonia [$0.56 (kg of NH
3
)
−1
] at a current density of >125 mA/cm
2
. In this sense, our results open an entirely new horizon for the renewable energy industry, where NO can be selectively captured from waste chemicals and renewably converted to a more value-added chemical, i.e., ammonia.

Figure 5. Economic estimation for electrochemical NORR to ammonia in the PBS-MC
200
-NO
s
electrolyte. Effect of current density and electricity price on the unit ammonia production cost with the global renewable electricity price.

Ammonia synthesis by N2 and steam electrolysis in molten hydroxide suspensions of nanoscale Fe2O3
Licht, Stuart; Cui, Baochen; Wang, Baohui; Li, Fang-Fang; Lau, Jason; Liu, Shuzhi

The Haber-Bosch process to produce ammonia for fertilizer currently relies on carbon-intensive steam reforming of methane as a hydrogen source. We present an electrochem. pathway in which ammonia is produced by electrolysis of air and steam in a molten hydroxide suspension of nano-Fe2O3. At 200°C in an electrolyte with a molar ratio of 0.5 NaOH/0.5 KOH, ammonia is produced at 1.2 V (V) under 2 mA cm-2 of applied current at coulombic efficiency of 35% (35% of the applied current results in the six-electron conversion of N2 and water to ammonia, and excess H2 is cogenerated with the ammonia). At 250°C and 25 bar of steam pressure, the electrolysis voltage necessary for 2 mA cm-2 c.d. decreased to 1.0 V.

An Electrochemical Haber-Bosch Process
Kyriakou, Vasileios; Garagounis, Ioannis; Vourros, Anastasios; Vasileiou, Eirini; Stoukides, Michael

Ammonia, produced via the Haber-Bosch (HB) process, is globally the leading chem. in energy consumption and carbon dioxide emissions. In ammonia plants, hydrogen is generated by steam-methane reforming (SMR) and water-gas shift (WGS) and, subsequently, is purified for the high-pressure ammonia synthesis. Herein, we demonstrate how these steps are integrated into a single BaZrO3-based protonic ceramic membrane reactor (PCMR), operating at atm. pressure. Hydrogen generation occurs on a Ni-composite electrode, while VN-Fe is the ammonia synthesis electrocatalyst. Hydrogen extn. from the reforming compartment enhances the thermodynamically limited methane conversions, whereas 5%-14% of the pumped protons are converted to ammonia. An electrochem. HB is designed by combining this PCMR with a protonic ceramic fuel cell to recover electricity and sep. nitrogen from ambient air by exploiting byproduct hydrogen. This process could potentially require less energy and release less carbon dioxide emissions than its conventional counterpart, holding promise for sustainable decentralized applications.

Greening Ammonia toward the Solar Ammonia Refinery
Wang, Lu; Xia, Meikun; Wang, Hong; Huang, Kefeng; Qian, Chenxi; Maravelias, Christos T.; Ozin, Geoffrey A.

In light of the targets set out by the Paris Climate Agreement and the global energy sector's ongoing transition from fossil fuels to renewables, the chem. industry is searching for innovative ways of reducing greenhouse gas emissions assocd. with the prodn. of ammonia. To address this need, research and development is under way around the world to replace the century-old Haber-Bosch process for manufg. ammonia from N2 and H2, powered by renewable electricity. This involves replacing H2 obtained from steam-reformed CH4 to H2 that is instead obtained from electrolyzed H2O. This transition will enable the changeover from the Haber-Bosch prodn. of NH3 to electrochem., plasma chem., thermochem., and photochem. generation of NH3. If ammonia can eventually be produced directly from N2 and H2O powered by just sunlight, at a technol. significant scale, efficiency, and cost, in a "solar ammonia refinery," green ammonia can change the world!

Production of ammonia via a chemical looping process based on metal imides as nitrogen carriers
Gao, Wenbo; Guo, Jianping; Wang, Peikun; Wang, Qianru; Chang, Fei; Pei, Qijun; Zhang, Weijin; Liu, Lin; Chen, Ping

Ammonia is a promising carbon-free energy carrier, but is currently synthesized industrially under harsh conditions. Synthesizing ammonia using lower temps. and pressures could therefore improve its prospects as a chem. means to store and transport energy. Here we report that alkali and alk. earth metal imides function as nitrogen carriers that mediate ammonia prodn. via a two-step chem. looping process operating under mild conditions. Nitrogen is first fixed through the redn. of N2 by alkali or alk. earth metal hydrides to form imides and, subsequently, the imides are hydrogenated to produce NH3 and regenerate the metal hydrides. The oxidn. state of hydrogen therefore switches between -1 (hydride), 0 (H2) and +1 (imide and NH3). Late 3d metals accelerate the reaction rates of both steps. The chem. loop mediated by BaNH and catalyzed by Ni produces NH3 at 100 °C and atm. pressure.

A review. Ammonia is an important nutrient for the growth of plants. In industry, ammonia is produced by the energy expensive Haber-Bosch process where dihydrogen and dinitrogen form ammonia at a very high pressure and temp. In principle one could also reduce dinitrogen upon addn. of protons and electrons similar to the mechanism of ammonia prodn. by nitrogenases. Recently, major breakthroughs have taken place in our understanding of biol. fixation of dinitrogen, of mol. model systems that can reduce dinitrogen, and in the electrochem. redn. of dinitrogen at heterogeneous surfaces. Yet for efficient redn. of dinitrogen with protons and electrons major hurdles still have to be overcome. The authors give an overview of the different catalytic systems, highlight the recent breakthroughs, pinpoint common grounds and discuss the bottlenecks and challenges in catalytic redn. of dinitrogen.

CO2 emissions and mitigation potential in China's ammonia industry
Zhou, Wenji; Zhu, Bing; Li, Qiang; Ma, Tieju; Hu, Shanying; Griffy-Brown, Charla

Significant pressure from increasing CO2 emissions and energy consumption in China's industrialization process has highlighted a need to understand and mitigate the sources of these emissions. Ammonia prodn., as one of the most important fundamental industries in China, represents those heavy industries that contribute largely to this sharp increasing trend. In the country with the largest population in the world, ammonia output has undergone fast growth spurred by increasing demand for fertilizer of food prodn. since 1950s. However, various types of technologies implemented in the industry make ammonia plants in China operate with huge differences in both energy consumption and CO2 emissions. With consideration of these unique features, this paper attempts to est. the amt. of CO2 emission from China's ammonia prodn., and analyze the potential for carbon mitigation in the industry. Based on the estn., related policy implications and measures required to realize the potential for mitigation are also discussed.

A rigorous electrochemical ammonia synthesis protocol with quantitative isotope measurements
Andersen, Suzanne Z.; Colic, Viktor; Yang, Sungeun; Schwalbe, Jay A.; Nielander, Adam C.; McEnaney, Joshua M.; Enemark-Rasmussen, Kasper; Baker, Jon G.; Singh, Aayush R.; Rohr, Brian A.; Statt, Michael J.; Blair, Sarah J.; Mezzavilla, Stefano; Kibsgaard, Jakob; Vesborg, Peter C. K.; Cargnello, Matteo; Bent, Stacey F.; Jaramillo, Thomas F.; Stephens, Ifan E. L.; Noerskov, Jens K.; Chorkendorff, Ib

),

(

The electrochem. synthesis of ammonia from nitrogen under mild conditions using renewable electricity is an attractive alternative1-4 to the energy-intensive Haber-Bosch process, which dominates industrial ammonia prodn. However, there are considerable scientific and tech. challenges5,6 facing the electrochem. alternative, and most exptl. studies reported so far have achieved only low selectivities and conversions. The amt. of ammonia produced is usually so small that it cannot be firmly attributed to electrochem. nitrogen fixation7-9 rather than contamination from ammonia that is either present in air, human breath or ion-conducting membranes9, or generated from labile nitrogen-contg. compds. (for example, nitrates, amines, nitrites and nitrogen oxides) that are typically present in the nitrogen gas stream10, in the atm. or even in the catalyst itself. Although these sources of exptl. artifacts are beginning to be recognized and managed11,12, concerted efforts to develop effective electrochem. nitrogen redn. processes would benefit from benchmarking protocols for the reaction and from a standardized set of control expts. designed to identify and then eliminate or quantify the sources of contamination. Here we propose a rigorous procedure using 15N2 that enables us to reliably detect and quantify the electrochem. redn. of nitrogen to ammonia. We demonstrate exptl. the importance of various sources of contamination, and show how to remove labile nitrogen-contg. compds. from the nitrogen gas as well as how to perform quant. isotope measurements with cycling of 15N2 gas to reduce both contamination and the cost of isotope measurements. Following this protocol, we find that no ammonia is produced when using the most promising pure-metal catalysts for this reaction in aq. media, and we successfully confirm and quantify ammonia synthesis using lithium electrodeposition in tetrahydrofuran13. The use of this rigorous protocol should help to prevent false positives from appearing in the literature, thus enabling the field to focus on viable pathways towards the practical electrochem. redn. of nitrogen to ammonia.

Electrochem. redn. of N2 to NH3 under ambient conditions can provide an alternative to the Haber-Bosch process for distributed NH3 prodn. that can be powered by renewable electricity. The major challenge for realizing such a process is to develop efficient electrocatalysts for the N2 redn. reaction (N2RR), as typical catalysts show a low activity and selectivity due to the barrier for N2 activation and the competing H evolution reaction (HER). Here the authors report an Fe/Fe3O4 catalyst for ambient electrochem. NH3 synthesis, which was prepd. by oxidizing an Fe foil at 300° followed by in situ electrochem. redn. The Fe/Fe3O4 catalyst exhibits a faradaic efficiency of 8.29% for NH3 prodn. at -0.3 V vs. the reversible H electrode in phosphate buffer soln., which is ∼120 times higher than that of the original Fe foil. The high selectivity is enabled by an enhancement of the intrinsic (surface-area-normalized) N2RR activity by up to 9-fold as well as an effective suppression of the HER activity. The N2RR selectivity of the Fe/Fe3O4 catalyst is also higher than that of Fe, Fe3O4, and Fe2O3 nanoparticles, suggesting Fe/Fe oxide composite to be an efficient catalyst for ambient electrochem. NH3 synthesis.

NH3 was synthesized directly from H2O and N2 at room temp. and atm. pressure in a flow electrochem. cell operating in gas phase (half-cell for the NH3 synthesis). Fe supported on C nanotubes (CNTs) was used as the electrocatalyst in this half-cell. A rate of NH3 formation of 2.2 × 10-3 gNH3 m-2 h-1 was obtained at room temp. and atm. pressure in a flow of N2, with stable behavior for at least 60 h of reaction, under an applied potential of -2.0 V. This value is higher than the rate of NH3 formation obtained using noble metals (Ru/C) under comparable reaction conditions. Also, H gas with a total Faraday efficiency ≤95.1% was obtained. Also the active sites in NH3 electrocatalytic synthesis may be assocd. to specific C sites formed at the interface between Fe particles and CNT and able to activate N2, making it more reactive towards hydrogenation.

The electrochem. synthesis of NH3 by the nitrogen redn. reaction (NRR) at low temp. (< 65°) and atm. pressure using nanosized γ-Fe2O3 electrocatalysts were demonstrated. The activity and selectivity of the catalyst was investigated both in a 0.1 M KOH electrolyte and when incorporated into an anion-exchange membrane electrode assembly (MEA). In a half-reaction expt. conducted in a KOH electrolyte, the γ-Fe2O3 electrode presented a faradaic efficiency of 1.9% and a wt.-normalized activity of 12.5 nmol h-1 mg-1 at 0.0 VRHE. However, the selectivity toward N2 redn. decreased at more neg. potentials owing to the competing proton redn. reaction. When the γ-Fe2O3 nanoparticles were coated onto porous carbon paper to form an electrode for a MEA, their wt.-normalized activity for N2 redn. was found to increase dramatically to 55.9 nmol h-1 mg-1. However, the wt.- and area-normalized N2 redn. activities of γ-Fe2O3 decreased progressively from 35.9-14.8 nmol h-1 mg-1 and from 0.105-0.043 nmol h-1 cm-2act, resp., during a 25 h MEA durability test. In summary, a study of the fundamental behavior and catalytic activity of γ-Fe2O3 nanoparticles in the electrochem. synthesis of NH3 under low temp. and pressure is presented.

The electrochem. nitrogen redn. reaction (ENRR) can allow the prodn. of ammonia from nitrogen and water under ambient conditions and is regarded as a sustainable alternative to the industrial Haber-Bosch process. However, electrocatalytic systems that selectively and efficiently catalyze nitrogen redn. remain elusive due to the strong competition with the hydrogen evolution reaction. Here, we report a strategy to simultaneously promote ENRR selectivity and activity using bismuth nanocrystals and potassium cations. Bismuth exhibits higher intrinsic ENRR activity than transition metals due to the strong interaction between the Bi 6p band and the N 2p orbitals. Potassium cations stabilize key nitrogen-redn. intermediates and regulate proton transfer to increase the selectivity. A high Faradaic efficiency of 66% and ammonia yield of 200 mmol g-1 h-1 (0.052 mmol cm-2 h-1) are obtained in aq. electrolyte under ambient conditions. This strategy represents a general method to expand the library of catalysts and promoters for the selective electrochem. redn. of stable mols.

As one of the most important chems. and carbon-free energy carriers, ammonia (NH3) has a worldwide annual prodn. of ∼150 million tons, and is mainly produced by the traditional high-temp. and high-pressure Haber-Bosch process which consumes massive amts. of energy. Very recently, electrocatalytic and photo(electro)catalytic redn. of N2 to NH3, which can be performed at ambient conditions using renewable energy, have received tremendous attention. The overall performance of these electrocatalytic and photo(electro)catalytic systems is largely dictated by their core components, catalysts. This perspective for the first time highlights the rational design of electrocatalysts and photo(electro)catalysts for N2 redn. to NH3 under ambient conditions. Fundamental theory of catalytic reaction pathways for the N2 redn. reaction and the corresponding material design principles are introduced first. Then, recently developed electrocatalysts and photo(electro)catalysts are summarized, with a special emphasis on the relationship between their physicochem. properties and NH3 prodn. performance. Finally, the opportunities in this emerging research field, in particular, the strategy of combining exptl. and theor. techniques to design efficient and stable catalysts for NH3 prodn., are outlined.

NO removal from exhausted gas is necessary owing to its damage to environment. Meanwhile, the electrochem. NH3 synthesis (EAS) from N2 suffers from low reaction rate and faradaic efficiency (FE). Now, an alternative route for NH3 synthesis is proposed from exhaust NO via electrocatalysis. DFT calcns. indicate electrochem. NO redn. (NORR) is more active than N2 redn. (NRR). Via a descriptor-based approach, Cu was screened out to be the most active transition metal catalyst for NORR to NH3 owing to its moderate reactivity. Kinetic barrier calcns. reveal NH3 is the most preferred product relative to H2, N2O, and N2 on Cu. Exptl., a record-high EAS rate of 517.1μmol cm-2 h-1 and FE of 93.5% were achieved at -0.9 V vs. RHE using a Cu foam electrode, exhibiting stable electrocatalytic performances with a 100 h run. This work provides an alternative strategy to EAS from exhaust NO, coupled with NO removal.

In this short crit. perspective, we outline the serious problems caused by air pollution in Europe. Using two types of metrics, level assessment and trend assessment, we quantify the contribution of ammonia, NOx, SOx, non-methane volatile org. compds., and particulate matter in terms of years of life lost per capita and explain the connection between the various pollutants and their effects on human health and the environment. This is done on the basis of data collected by individual European Union (EU) member states as well as by the EU as a whole. We examine general emission trends as well as sector-specific emissions and discuss the effectiveness of current legislation in reducing health risks and environmental damage. By combining these results with a cost-benefit anal., we show that a further redn. in NOx emissions is the most urgent and potentially the most beneficial.

Aqueous diffusivities and solubilities of NO were determined by using a chemiluminescence detector to measure time-dependent fluxes across stagnant liquid films confined between polydimethylsiloxane membranes. The NO diffusivities in pure water and PBS at 25 degrees C were found to be (2.21+/-0.02) x 10(-5) cm2 s(-1) and (2.21+/-0.04) x 10(-5) cm2 s(-1), respectively. Although lower than most previous values for NO at room temperature, these diffusivities are very similar to those for O2, as one would expect. Extrapolation to 37 degrees C yielded a value of 3.0 x 10(-5) cm2 s(-1). The solubility of NO in water at 25 degrees C was (1.94+/-0.03) x 10(-6) mol cm(-3) atm(-1), in agreement with the literature. This agreement, along with the excellent fits obtained to the transient flux data (<4% rms error in each experiment), supports the validity of the simultaneously measured diffusivity. The solubility of NO in PBS at 25 degrees C was (1.75+/-0.02) x 10(-6) mol cm(-3) atm(-1). The modest (10%) reduction in solubility relative to that in pure water is consistent with the usual effects of salts on gas solubilities.

The combustion of fossil fuels generates SO2 and NOx pollutants which cause acid rain and urban smog. Existing flue-gas desulfurization scrubbers involve wet limestone processes which efficiently control SO2 emissions, but are incapable of removing water-insol. NO. The current technique for post-combustion control of NO emissions, NH3-based selective catalytic redn., suffers from various problems, including poisoning of the catalysts by fly ash rich in As or alkali, disposal of spent toxic catalysts, and the effects of NH3 byproducts on plant components downstream from the reactor. To circumvent the need for sep. schemes to control SO2 and NOx, iron(II) thiochelate complex was developed that enhances the soly. of NO in aq. soln. by rapidly and efficiently absorbing NO to form iron nitrosyl complexes. The bound NO is then converted to NH3 by electrochem. redn., regenerating the active iron(II) catalyst for continued NO capture. Results suggest that this process can be readily integrated into existing wet limestone scrubbers for the simultaneous removal of SO2 and NOx.

The absorption of nitric oxide into aq. solns. of ferrous chelates of nitrilotriacetic acid (NTA), EDTA, hydroxyethylenediaminetriacetic acid (HEDTA), and diethylenetriaminepentaacetic acid (DTPA) was studied in a stirred cell reactor. Exptl. conditions were as follows: 0.05 ≤ CFe(II)L ≤ 0.1 kmol/m3, 8 ≤ PNO ≤ 30 kPa, 3 ≤ pH ≤ 10 (NTA), or 7 ≤ pH ≤ 8 (EDTA, HEDTA, DTPA), CL ≤ CFe(II) ≤ 3CL (NTA) or CL = CFe(II) (EDTA, HEDTA, DTPA), and 293 ≤ T ≤ 333 K (NTA, EDTA, HEDTA) or T = 294 K (DTPA). The absorption leads to stable ferrous NO chelates. Due to the high reaction rate, in combination with the relatively high PNO applied, the absorption rate is strongly affected by mass transfer limitation only. By applying penetration theory, the ratio of the diffusion coeffs. of ferrous chelates and NO was detd.: at T = 294 K, (DFe(II)chelate/DNO)1/2 = 0.44 ±0.01, 0.34 ±0.01, 0.36 ±0.01, and 0.31 ±0.015, for the ferrous NTA, HEDTA, EDTA, and DTPA complexes, resp. At elevated T, (DFe(II)chelate/DNO)1/2 decreases due to the unusual T-dependency of DNO. For ferrous NTA, the formation of the ferrous NO chelate is accompanied by pH effects that can be understood from iron chelate chem. In the case of ferrous NTA, pH <5, or an excess of ligand, these effects lead to local pH gradients at the gas-liq. interface that substantially affect the NO absorption rates. Kinetic data from the literature on the absorption of NO into ferrous chelates were evaluated using the mass transfer parameters detd. These kinetic data are often unreliable.

Low-dimensional materials and their hybrids have emerged as promising candidates for electrocatalytic and photocatalytic hydrogen evolution and CO2 conversion into useful mols. Progress in synthetic methods for the prodn. of catalysts coupled with a better understanding of the fundamental catalytic mechanisms has enabled the rational design of catalytic nanomaterials with improved performance and selectivity. In this Review, we analyze the state of the art in the implementation of low-dimensional nanomaterials and their van der Waals heterostructures for hydrogen evolution and CO2 redn. by electrocatalysis and photocatalysis. We explore the mechanisms involved in both reactions and the different strategies to further optimize the activity, efficiency and selectivity of low-dimensional catalysts.

Suter, Silvan; Haussener, Sophia

Mesostructured silver catalysts have shown a substantial rise in reaction selectivity for the conversion of CO2 into fuels with increasing thickness of ordered, inverse-opal films. The challenge lies in the optimization of the morphol. to maximize the CO selectivity. We developed a 3D mass transport model utilizing the accurate electrode geometry to calc. local concn. distributions of CO2(aq), OH-, HCO3-, and CO32- by considering the buffer reactions in the electrolyte and modeling local catalytic surface reaction rates based on Butler-Volmer correlations. Validated with exptl. data from the literature, the model predicted the suppression of the hydrogen evolution reaction with an inverse dependency on the hydroxide concn. and the promotion of the CO evolution reaction with a proportional dependency on the carbonate concn. In order to increase the CO selectivity, we developed design guidelines that suggest high electrode roughness per film thickness, which translates to smaller pore size in practice. Further, the shallow pores of the electrode strongly reduced the overall CO selectivity as the mass transport to the bulk was non-limiting. We demonstrated that the introduction of an addnl. diffusion layer on top of the silver electrode can enhance the CO selectivity from as low as 39% to more than 90%.

A review. The reactivity of nitric oxide on various metal electrodes is discussed. The significant differences between the reactivity of adsorbed NO and NO in soln. are pointed out, both for the redn. and the oxidn. reaction(s). Whereas adsorbed NO can be reduced only to hydroxylamine and/or NH3, it takes NO in soln. to produce N2O and N2. From the redn. of NO on a series on stepped single-crystal Pt electrodes, NOads redn. is not a structure sensitive process. The protonation of the adsorbed NO is rate-detg.; neither the NO adsorption strength nor the N-O bond breaking play a significant role in its redn. rate. Whereas adsorbed NO on polycryst. Pt can only be oxidized to nitrate, in the presence of NO in soln. nitrous acid HNO2 may also be formed, in a potential region where adsorbed NO is otherwise stable. On Pt(111) and Pt(554) NOads may be oxidized to HNO2 in a surface-bonded redox couple. Whereas surface oxides appear to catalyze the oxidn. of soln. NO to HNO2, the further oxidn. to nitrate seems to be inhibited by the presence of surface oxides. Both the redn. and oxidn. of soln. NO appear to be not very metal-dependent reactions, as they take place with approx. equal rate on all electrode metals studied, including Au. This behavior suggests the involvement of weakly adsorbed intermediates, and the relatively unimportant role of surface-bonded NO in the bulk NO redn. and oxidn. activity.

de Vooys, A. C. A.; Koper, M. T. M.; van Santen, R. A.; van Veen, J. A. R.

The mechanism of the electrochem. redn. of nitric oxide (NO) on a series of metals (Pd, Rh, Ru, Ir, and Au) has been studied, both for the redn. of adsorbed NO and for the continuous NO redn. All metals show a high selectivity to N2O at high potentials and a high selectivity to NH3 at low potentials, whereas N2 is formed at intermediate potentials (although gold forms mainly N2O, and very little NH3). The behavior of the transition metals is very similar to that of platinum, suggesting that the reaction schemes are essentially the same (esp. the potential windows in which the products are formed are similar). The mechanism that leads to N2O is believed to involve the formation of a weakly adsorbed NO dimer intermediate, similar to recent suggestions made for the gas-phase redn. of NO. The redn. of adsorbed NO leads only to formation of NH3 and not to N2O or N2. The electrochem. measurements suggest that NH3 formation involves a combined electron-proton transfer in equil., followed by a nonelectrochem. rate-detg. step. The formation of N2, produced at potentials between the formation of N2O and NH3, most likely takes place by the redn. of previously formed N2O. (c) 2001 Academic Press.

The dependence of the rate of N2O formation on reactant concns. and on pH in the oxidn. of NH2OH by Fe(III) was investigated, with emphasis on low concns. of NH2OH. The prodn. rate of N2O is pseudo 1st order with respect to total Fe, pseudo 1st order or less with respect to total NH2OH, and inversely proportional to [H+]2.5. The reaction is highly sensitive to temp. Of the competing reactions producing nitrogenous products other than N2O, ≥1 is catalyzed by light. An empirical rate law based on the total concns. of the reactants is presented, and a more general rate law based on the concns. of presumed reactive species is derived.

The reduction of NH2OH in acid soln. by some metals in lower oxidation states, normally leading to NH3 and H2O (Kurtenacker and Werner, C.A. 21, 1914), yields kinetic data in the presence of methyl methacrylate, C6H6, toluene, BzH, C10H7SO3H, C6H4MeSO3H, and PhSO3H, which indicate that the reduction is 2-step. The 1st step is Mn+ + HONH3+ → M(n+1)+ + NH2 + (OH- + H+). The NH2 radical produced is an effective initiator of polymerization of Me methacrylate. Although the reaction products formed by NH2 and C6H6 could not be completely detd., biphenyl is one product formed, possibly from C6H6.NH2, which undergoes other reactions in addn. to dimerization. A consideration of heats of reaction shows the proposed 1st step is 12.5 kcal. more exothermic than the alternative Mn+ + HONH3+ → M(n + 1)+ + OH + (H+ + NH2-). In most of the expts. Ti(III) was used as the reducing agent, but Cr(II), V(II), Mo(III), and Fe(II) also produced polymerization in the presence of Me methacrylate although at slower rates.

The kinetics of oxidn. of hydroxylamine by iron(III) have been studied spectrophotometrically. The effects of pH, reactant and product concns. led to two exptl. rate expressions. The results obtained are consistent with a mechanism dependent on the relative iron(III)-to-hydroxylamine concns.; an excess of iron(III) gives a stoichiometry of 2 : 1 for the total reaction and N2O as the oxidn. product, whereas at equal amts. or excess of hydroxylamine the stoichiometry reduces to 1 : 1 with N2 as the main product . In the latter case the rate expression -d[Fe(III)]/dt = k[Fe(III)]2[NH2OH]2/[Fe(II)]2[H+]4 is obtained. The consistent mechanism identifies two pre-equil. and the reaction of two different nitrogen-contg. intermediates as the rate-detg. step depending on the reactant ratios. The proposed mechanism does also involve the metal hydroxide complex Fe(OH)2+, in agreement with previous results.

The rate of decompn. of trioxodinitrate monobasic anion (HN2O3-) in aq. soln. is unaffected by the presence of hydroxylamine, but the primary product nitroxyl (HNO) experiences a competition between dimerization to N2O and redn. to N2. The proportion of N2 increases with pH and with NH2OH concn.; at pH 8, with NH2OH in 10-fold excess over HN2O3-, the reaction product is more than 97% N2. The reaction between NO and NH2OH produces equimolar amts. of N2 and N2O at pH >13, but the ratio N2/N2O decreases with pH; at pH 8 the product is almost entirely N2O. The rate of reaction declines sharply with decreasing pH. Observations of reaction product ratios are complicated by simultaneous contributions of NH2OH disproportionation, which produces N2 and N2O in pH-dependent proportions. Tracer expts. employing 15N18O reactant confirm a previously proposed mechanistic interpretation of the NO-NH2OH reaction in detail: a N-bound H atom is abstracted by NO to form HNO and the radical NHOH. The radical combines with a second NO mol. to form nitrosohydroxylamine, which in turn produces two kinds of N2O: I, predominantly 14N15N18O, and II, predominantly 15N14N16O. The asym. of the intermediate is reflected in a higher proportion of I than II in the product at high pH, but these proportions become equalized at pH, probably because of tautomerism in the intermediate. Nitroxyl is entirely reduced by NH2OH to N2 at high pH but undergoes dimerization to produce a third kind of N2O, predominantly 15N15N18O, to an extent that increases with decreasing pH. The tracer expts. also provide support for the hypothesis that nitroxyl is a primary product of hydroxylamine disproportionation. Since the nitroxyl produced in HN2O3- decompn. is preferentially reduced to N2 at pH 8 in the presence of NH2OH, while the nitroxyl produced in the NONH2OH reaction is almost entirely consumed by self-reaction at the same pH, different intermediate species are produced in these two reactions.

A method to obtain the stability of reaction intermediates of electrochem. processes using electronic structure calcns. is presented. This method is used in combination with detailed d. functional calcns. to develop a detailed description of the free-energy landscape of the electrochem. O redn. reaction over Pt(111), as a function of applied bias. This allowed identification of the origin of the overpotential of this reaction. Adsorbed O and hydroxyl are stable intermediates at potentials close to equil., and the calcd. rate const. for the activated p/electron transfer to adsorbed O or hydroxyl can account quant. for the obsd. kinetics. From a database of calcd. O and hydroxyl adsorption energies, the trends in the O redn. rate for a large no. of different transition and noble metals can be explained. Alternative reaction mechanisms involving p/electron transfer to adsorbed mol. O were also considered, and this peroxide mechanism dominates for most noble metals. The model suggests ways to improve the electrocatalytic properties of fuel cell cathodes.

Carbon-supported iron complexes were investigated as electrocatalysts for the redn. of nitric oxide (NO) in a H2-NO fuel cell conceived for the prodn. of hydroxylamine (NH2OH) with concomitant generation of electricity. Two types of iron complexes with tetradentate ligands, namely bis(salicylidene)ethylenediimine (Salen) and phthalocyanine (Pc), supported on activated carbon or graphite were prepd. and evaluated as electrocatalysts, either without further treatment or after pyrolysis at 700 °C. The performance in the redn. of NO of gas diffusion cathodes based on these electrocatalysts was investigated in an electrochem. half cell (3-electrode configuration) using linear sweep voltammetry (LSV). The most promising electrocatalysts were studied further by chronoamperometric expts. in a H2-NO fuel cell, which allowed comparison in terms of power output and hydroxylamine prodn. Depending on the concn. of the NO feed (6 or 18%), the best electrocatalytic performance was delivered either by FePc or FeSalen. The gas diffusion electrode based on FeSalen supported on activated carbon with 0.3 wt% Fe-loading provided the highest c.d. (86 A/m2) and the best current efficiency (43%) towards the desired NH2OH when operating at the higher NO concn. (18%). Moreover, FeSalen offers the advantage of being cheaper than FePc. The exptl. work was complemented by d. functional theory (DFT) calcns., which allowed to shed more light on the reaction mechanism for the redn. of nitric oxide at the atomistic level.

Ammonia synthesis by N2 and steam electrolysis in molten hydroxide suspensions of nanoscale Fe2O3
Licht, Stuart; Cui, Baochen; Wang, Baohui; Li, Fang-Fang; Lau, Jason; Liu, Shuzhi
Science (Washington, DC, United States)
(
2014
),
345
(
6197

637-640
CODEN:
SCIEAS
; ISSN:
0036-8075
.
(
American Association for the Advancement of Science
)
The Haber-Bosch process to produce ammonia for fertilizer currently relies on carbon-intensive steam reforming of methane as a hydrogen source. We present an electrochem. pathway in which ammonia is produced by electrolysis of air and steam in a molten hydroxide suspension of nano-Fe2O3. At 200°C in an electrolyte with a molar ratio of 0.5 NaOH/0.5 KOH, ammonia is produced at 1.2 V (V) under 2 mA cm-2 of applied current at coulombic efficiency of 35% (35% of the applied current results in the six-electron conversion of N2 and water to ammonia, and excess H2 is cogenerated with the ammonia). At 250°C and 25 bar of steam pressure, the electrolysis voltage necessary for 2 mA cm-2 c.d. decreased to 1.0 V.

An Electrochemical Haber-Bosch Process
Kyriakou, Vasileios; Garagounis, Ioannis; Vourros, Anastasios; Vasileiou, Eirini; Stoukides, Michael
Joule
(

Cell Press

Ammonia, produced via the Haber-Bosch (HB) process, is globally the leading chem. in energy consumption and carbon dioxide emissions. In ammonia plants, hydrogen is generated by steam-methane reforming (SMR) and water-gas shift (WGS) and, subsequently, is purified for the high-pressure ammonia synthesis. Herein, we demonstrate how these steps are integrated into a single BaZrO3-based protonic ceramic membrane reactor (PCMR), operating at atm. pressure. Hydrogen generation occurs on a Ni-composite electrode, while VN-Fe is the ammonia synthesis electrocatalyst. Hydrogen extn. from the reforming compartment enhances the thermodynamically limited methane conversions, whereas 5%-14% of the pumped protons are converted to ammonia. An electrochem. HB is designed by combining this PCMR with a protonic ceramic fuel cell to recover electricity and sep. nitrogen from ambient air by exploiting byproduct hydrogen. This process could potentially require less energy and release less carbon dioxide emissions than its conventional counterpart, holding promise for sustainable decentralized applications.

In light of the targets set out by the Paris Climate Agreement and the global energy sector's ongoing transition from fossil fuels to renewables, the chem. industry is searching for innovative ways of reducing greenhouse gas emissions assocd. with the prodn. of ammonia. To address this need, research and development is under way around the world to replace the century-old Haber-Bosch process for manufg. ammonia from N2 and H2, powered by renewable electricity. This involves replacing H2 obtained from steam-reformed CH4 to H2 that is instead obtained from electrolyzed H2O. This transition will enable the changeover from the Haber-Bosch prodn. of NH3 to electrochem., plasma chem., thermochem., and photochem. generation of NH3. If ammonia can eventually be produced directly from N2 and H2O powered by just sunlight, at a technol. significant scale, efficiency, and cost, in a "solar ammonia refinery," green ammonia can change the world!

Production of ammonia via a chemical looping process based on metal imides as nitrogen carriers
Gao, Wenbo; Guo, Jianping; Wang, Peikun; Wang, Qianru; Chang, Fei; Pei, Qijun; Zhang, Weijin; Liu, Lin; Chen, Ping
Nature Energy

Ammonia is a promising carbon-free energy carrier, but is currently synthesized industrially under harsh conditions. Synthesizing ammonia using lower temps. and pressures could therefore improve its prospects as a chem. means to store and transport energy. Here we report that alkali and alk. earth metal imides function as nitrogen carriers that mediate ammonia prodn. via a two-step chem. looping process operating under mild conditions. Nitrogen is first fixed through the redn. of N2 by alkali or alk. earth metal hydrides to form imides and, subsequently, the imides are hydrogenated to produce NH3 and regenerate the metal hydrides. The oxidn. state of hydrogen therefore switches between -1 (hydride), 0 (H2) and +1 (imide and NH3). Late 3d metals accelerate the reaction rates of both steps. The chem. loop mediated by BaNH and catalyzed by Ni produces NH3 at 100 °C and atm. pressure.

A review. Ammonia is an important nutrient for the growth of plants. In industry, ammonia is produced by the energy expensive Haber-Bosch process where dihydrogen and dinitrogen form ammonia at a very high pressure and temp. In principle one could also reduce dinitrogen upon addn. of protons and electrons similar to the mechanism of ammonia prodn. by nitrogenases. Recently, major breakthroughs have taken place in our understanding of biol. fixation of dinitrogen, of mol. model systems that can reduce dinitrogen, and in the electrochem. redn. of dinitrogen at heterogeneous surfaces. Yet for efficient redn. of dinitrogen with protons and electrons major hurdles still have to be overcome. The authors give an overview of the different catalytic systems, highlight the recent breakthroughs, pinpoint common grounds and discuss the bottlenecks and challenges in catalytic redn. of dinitrogen.

Significant pressure from increasing CO2 emissions and energy consumption in China's industrialization process has highlighted a need to understand and mitigate the sources of these emissions. Ammonia prodn., as one of the most important fundamental industries in China, represents those heavy industries that contribute largely to this sharp increasing trend. In the country with the largest population in the world, ammonia output has undergone fast growth spurred by increasing demand for fertilizer of food prodn. since 1950s. However, various types of technologies implemented in the industry make ammonia plants in China operate with huge differences in both energy consumption and CO2 emissions. With consideration of these unique features, this paper attempts to est. the amt. of CO2 emission from China's ammonia prodn., and analyze the potential for carbon mitigation in the industry. Based on the estn., related policy implications and measures required to realize the potential for mitigation are also discussed.

A rigorous electrochemical ammonia synthesis protocol with quantitative isotope measurements
Andersen, Suzanne Z.; Colic, Viktor; Yang, Sungeun; Schwalbe, Jay A.; Nielander, Adam C.; McEnaney, Joshua M.; Enemark-Rasmussen, Kasper; Baker, Jon G.; Singh, Aayush R.; Rohr, Brian A.; Statt, Michael J.; Blair, Sarah J.; Mezzavilla, Stefano; Kibsgaard, Jakob; Vesborg, Peter C. K.; Cargnello, Matteo; Bent, Stacey F.; Jaramillo, Thomas F.; Stephens, Ifan E. L.; Noerskov, Jens K.; Chorkendorff, Ib

Nature Research

The electrochem. synthesis of ammonia from nitrogen under mild conditions using renewable electricity is an attractive alternative1-4 to the energy-intensive Haber-Bosch process, which dominates industrial ammonia prodn. However, there are considerable scientific and tech. challenges5,6 facing the electrochem. alternative, and most exptl. studies reported so far have achieved only low selectivities and conversions. The amt. of ammonia produced is usually so small that it cannot be firmly attributed to electrochem. nitrogen fixation7-9 rather than contamination from ammonia that is either present in air, human breath or ion-conducting membranes9, or generated from labile nitrogen-contg. compds. (for example, nitrates, amines, nitrites and nitrogen oxides) that are typically present in the nitrogen gas stream10, in the atm. or even in the catalyst itself. Although these sources of exptl. artifacts are beginning to be recognized and managed11,12, concerted efforts to develop effective electrochem. nitrogen redn. processes would benefit from benchmarking protocols for the reaction and from a standardized set of control expts. designed to identify and then eliminate or quantify the sources of contamination. Here we propose a rigorous procedure using 15N2 that enables us to reliably detect and quantify the electrochem. redn. of nitrogen to ammonia. We demonstrate exptl. the importance of various sources of contamination, and show how to remove labile nitrogen-contg. compds. from the nitrogen gas as well as how to perform quant. isotope measurements with cycling of 15N2 gas to reduce both contamination and the cost of isotope measurements. Following this protocol, we find that no ammonia is produced when using the most promising pure-metal catalysts for this reaction in aq. media, and we successfully confirm and quantify ammonia synthesis using lithium electrodeposition in tetrahydrofuran13. The use of this rigorous protocol should help to prevent false positives from appearing in the literature, thus enabling the field to focus on viable pathways towards the practical electrochem. redn. of nitrogen to ammonia.

Electrochem. redn. of N2 to NH3 under ambient conditions can provide an alternative to the Haber-Bosch process for distributed NH3 prodn. that can be powered by renewable electricity. The major challenge for realizing such a process is to develop efficient electrocatalysts for the N2 redn. reaction (N2RR), as typical catalysts show a low activity and selectivity due to the barrier for N2 activation and the competing H evolution reaction (HER). Here the authors report an Fe/Fe3O4 catalyst for ambient electrochem. NH3 synthesis, which was prepd. by oxidizing an Fe foil at 300° followed by in situ electrochem. redn. The Fe/Fe3O4 catalyst exhibits a faradaic efficiency of 8.29% for NH3 prodn. at -0.3 V vs. the reversible H electrode in phosphate buffer soln., which is ∼120 times higher than that of the original Fe foil. The high selectivity is enabled by an enhancement of the intrinsic (surface-area-normalized) N2RR activity by up to 9-fold as well as an effective suppression of the HER activity. The N2RR selectivity of the Fe/Fe3O4 catalyst is also higher than that of Fe, Fe3O4, and Fe2O3 nanoparticles, suggesting Fe/Fe oxide composite to be an efficient catalyst for ambient electrochem. NH3 synthesis.

The electrochem. nitrogen redn. reaction (ENRR) can allow the prodn. of ammonia from nitrogen and water under ambient conditions and is regarded as a sustainable alternative to the industrial Haber-Bosch process. However, electrocatalytic systems that selectively and efficiently catalyze nitrogen redn. remain elusive due to the strong competition with the hydrogen evolution reaction. Here, we report a strategy to simultaneously promote ENRR selectivity and activity using bismuth nanocrystals and potassium cations. Bismuth exhibits higher intrinsic ENRR activity than transition metals due to the strong interaction between the Bi 6p band and the N 2p orbitals. Potassium cations stabilize key nitrogen-redn. intermediates and regulate proton transfer to increase the selectivity. A high Faradaic efficiency of 66% and ammonia yield of 200 mmol g-1 h-1 (0.052 mmol cm-2 h-1) are obtained in aq. electrolyte under ambient conditions. This strategy represents a general method to expand the library of catalysts and promoters for the selective electrochem. redn. of stable mols.

As one of the most important chems. and carbon-free energy carriers, ammonia (NH3) has a worldwide annual prodn. of ∼150 million tons, and is mainly produced by the traditional high-temp. and high-pressure Haber-Bosch process which consumes massive amts. of energy. Very recently, electrocatalytic and photo(electro)catalytic redn. of N2 to NH3, which can be performed at ambient conditions using renewable energy, have received tremendous attention. The overall performance of these electrocatalytic and photo(electro)catalytic systems is largely dictated by their core components, catalysts. This perspective for the first time highlights the rational design of electrocatalysts and photo(electro)catalysts for N2 redn. to NH3 under ambient conditions. Fundamental theory of catalytic reaction pathways for the N2 redn. reaction and the corresponding material design principles are introduced first. Then, recently developed electrocatalysts and photo(electro)catalysts are summarized, with a special emphasis on the relationship between their physicochem. properties and NH3 prodn. performance. Finally, the opportunities in this emerging research field, in particular, the strategy of combining exptl. and theor. techniques to design efficient and stable catalysts for NH3 prodn., are outlined.

NO removal from exhausted gas is necessary owing to its damage to environment. Meanwhile, the electrochem. NH3 synthesis (EAS) from N2 suffers from low reaction rate and faradaic efficiency (FE). Now, an alternative route for NH3 synthesis is proposed from exhaust NO via electrocatalysis. DFT calcns. indicate electrochem. NO redn. (NORR) is more active than N2 redn. (NRR). Via a descriptor-based approach, Cu was screened out to be the most active transition metal catalyst for NORR to NH3 owing to its moderate reactivity. Kinetic barrier calcns. reveal NH3 is the most preferred product relative to H2, N2O, and N2 on Cu. Exptl., a record-high EAS rate of 517.1μmol cm-2 h-1 and FE of 93.5% were achieved at -0.9 V vs. RHE using a Cu foam electrode, exhibiting stable electrocatalytic performances with a 100 h run. This work provides an alternative strategy to EAS from exhaust NO, coupled with NO removal.
